properties.title: 04/23/1564 - Stratford-upon-Avon, Henley St.
properties.content: William Shakespeare was born on Henley Street in Stratford-upon-Avon  1born on or around April 23, 1564.
properties.attribution: Drawn by Richard Greene (antiquary), engraving by Benjamin Cole, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 04/26/1564 - Stratford-upon-Avon, Holy Trinity Church
properties.content: William Shakespeare was baptized at Holy Trinity Church at Stratford-upon-avon on April 26, 1564.
properties.alt_text: A Painting of Stratford-upon-Avon's Holy Trinity Cathedral
properties.attribution: National Library of Wales, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 1571-1578 - Stratford-upon-Avon, King’s New School
properties.content: William Shakepeare likely attended King's New School, a grammar school for boys and learned Greek, Latin, and the Classics from 1571 to 1578..
properties.alt_text: Shakespeare's School, King's New School with Adjacent Guild Chapel
properties.attribution: Elliott Brown from Birmingham, United Kingdom, CC BY 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 11/28/1582 - Temple Grafton
properties.content: William Shakespeare married Anne Hathaway in Worchester and possibly in the parish of Temple Grafton on November 28, 1582. What is known is that it did not occur in Stratford-upon-Avon, for the bride was three months pregnant and the couple was seeking to avoid scandal by having the marriage
properties.alt_text: Very early sketch of Anne Hathaway
properties.attribution: JschneiderWiki, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 05/26/1583 - Stratford-upon-Avon, Holy Trinity Church
properties.content: Susanna Shakespeare, their first daughter, was baptized in Holy Trinity Church, like her father on May 26, 1583.
properties.alt_text: illustration of William Shakespeare reciting his play Hamlet to his family. His wife, Anne Hathaway, is sitting in the chair on the right; his son Hamnet is behind him on the left; his two daughters Susanna and Judith are on the right and left of him.
properties.attribution: Perine, George Edward, 1837-1885, printmaker., Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 02-02-1585 - Stratford-upon-Avon, Holy Trinity Church
properties.content: Hamnet and Judith, fraternal twins, were baptized in Holy Trinity Church on February 2nd, 1585.
properties.alt_text: Parish Register of Hamnet's and Judith's Baptism
properties.attribution: the vicar or clerk of the Holy Trinity Church, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 1585-1592 - "Lost Years"
properties.content: From 1585 to 1592 are known as the 'Lost Years,' of this period nothing is known of Shakespeare's existence.

properties.title: 1592 - London
properties.content: William Shakespeare was referenced in Robert Greene's pamphlet printed by the Worshipful Company of Stationers and Newsmakers. It makes allusion to Shakespeare's Henry VI Part III with the mocking line "Tygers hart wrapt in a Players hyde" and refers to him as an "upstart crow."
properties.attribution: John Dickenson, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 1594 - the Theatre, Shoreditch London
properties.content: Joins Lord Chamberlain's Men as actor and shareholder, writes and performs plays in the Theatre in Shoreditch.
properties.attribution: Joseph Quincy Adams - no image credit, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 1596 - Hamnet, Shakespeare's son dies
properties.content: Hamnet Shakespeare dies at Stratford-upon-Avon of "pestilence," most probably the bubonic plague.
properties.attribution: Wrad at en.wikipedia, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 1596 - St. Helen's Parish at Bishop's Gate
properties.content: William Shakespeare is listed as owing tax on a rented house near shoreditch in an affluent neighborhood, St. Helens.
properties.attribution: National Archives, U.K

properties.title: 1597 - Stratford-upon-Avon, New Place
properties.content: William Shakespeare buys New Place in Stratford-upon-Avon.
properties.alt_text: Local plan of Shakespeare's New Place
properties.attribution: Internet Archive Book Images, No restrictions, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 1597 - Shakespeare resides at Bankside
properties.content: Shakespeare lived at Bankside near the globe
properties.attribution: Internet Archive Book Images, No restrictions, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 1599 - London, South bank of the River Thames
properties.content: Construction of Globe Theatre
properties.attribution: C. Walter Hodges, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 1602 - Middle Temple Hall
properties.content: Shakespeare's play Twelfth Night debut here, at Middle Temple, on February 2nd, 1602.
properties.attribution: Middle Temple, London, sketch by Thomas Shepherd, c.1830

properties.title: 1603 - London
properties.content: Lord Chamberlain’s Men renamed to King's Men
properties.alt_text: Picture of the King's Men patron, James VI and I.
properties.attribution: Attributed to John de Critz, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 1604 - Barbican - London
properties.content: Shakespeare rents at a house on the corner of Silver and Monkwell
properties.attribution: Cobbe Collection, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 1608 - London, Blackfriars Theatre
properties.content: King's Men take over Blackfriars Theatre
properties.attribution: G. Topham Forrest, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 1613 - London, South bank of the River Thames
properties.content: Globe Theatre burns down
properties.alt_text: Map of the theatres in London
properties.attribution: London_theatres_C16—C17,_after_Redwood.svg: *London_map_showing_Shakespearean_theatres.png: Joseph Quincy Adams. Image credit C. W. Redwood, formerly technical artist at Cornell Universityderivative work: Old Moonrakerderivative work: Old Moonraker, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 1613 - London, near Blackfriars
properties.content: Shakespeare buys house near the Blackfriars Theatre in London from William Underhill.
properties.attribution: Attributed to John Taylor, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 1613-1616 - Stratford-upon-Avon, New Place
properties.content: Sometime between 1613 and 1616 Shakespeare retires to New Place.
properties.attribution: Internet Archive Book Images, No restrictions, via Wikimedia Commons

properties.title: 04/23/1616 - Stratford-upon-Avon, Holy Trinity Church
properties.content: William Shakespeare dies at Stratford-upon-Avon and is buried at Holy Trinity Church.
properties.attribution: Tom Reedy, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
